## Journal choices

::::::: answer-box
::: {.callout-important title="ğŸ’  Diamond Open Access" collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Diamond OA provides immediate free access to articles without charging *article processing charges* (APCs) to authors. Journals are supported by institutions, scholarly societies, grants, consortia, or volunteer labor. Articles are often published under open licenses (e.g., [CC BY](https://creativecommons.org/share-your-work/cclicenses/)), enabling reuse and broad dissemination.

-   **advantage**: equitable for both authors and readers, freely accessible to anyone

-   **drawback**: sustainability depends on external funding or unpaid labor
:::

::: {.callout-important title="ğŸ¥‡ Gold Open Access" collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Gold OA makes the final published article immediately free on the publisherâ€™s site. Funding commonly comes from *article processing charges* (APCs) paid by authors, institutions, or funders. Articles are often published under open licenses (e.g., [CC BY](https://creativecommons.org/share-your-work/cclicenses/)), enabling reuse and broad dissemination.

-   **advantage**: maximum visibility and compliance with OA mandates, freely accessible to anyone

-   **drawback**: APCs can exclude authors without funding
:::

::: {.callout-important title="ğŸ“” Conventional publishing (\"closed\" access)" collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Conventional "closed" journals restrict access to subscribers or pay-per-view users. Publishers generate revenue only from individual or institutional subscriptions because authors typically do not pay publication fees. Content is usually under publisher-controlled licenses, limiting reuse and redistribution.

-   **advantage**: you get to (in many fields still) the best-known and widest reaching journals

-   **drawback**: limited readership and barriers to access
:::

::: {.callout-important title="â‰ï¸ Predatory journals" collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Predatory journals publish the article immediately without any direct peer review. The author is charged lower publication fees, but the editors provide little or no quality control, archiving or indexing.

-   **advantage**: fast processing and easy acceptance, (may be) freely accessible to anyone

-   **drawback**: low quality assurance, risk to author reputation and career, higher costs and lack of transparency
:::
:::::::
